<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
February/March 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 227, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 353, 910, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 806, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 406, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
A ball falls from rest through the air towards the ground. The diagram shows two forces acting on the ball.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 448, 593, 586]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 597, 484, 615]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 626, 348, 644]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 134, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 655, 467, 673]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 682, 131, 700]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 682, 467, 700]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 698, 89]]<|/det|> A compressed spring projects a ball horizontally in a vacuum chamber. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 737, 119]]<|/det|> On the Earth, the ball reaches the chamber floor \(4.0 \text{m}\) in front of the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 920, 165]]<|/det|> An identical experiment is done on the Moon. The gravitational field strength is lower on the Moon than on the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 177, 751, 195]]<|/det|> The experimental results on the Moon are compared with those on the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 208, 348, 225]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 236, 134, 254]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 236, 920, 269]]<|/det|> The horizontal speed is greater on the Moon and the ball hits the floor \(4.0 \text{m}\) in front of the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 276, 131, 293]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 276, 920, 310]]<|/det|> The horizontal speed is greater on the Moon and the ball hits the floor more than \(4.0 \text{m}\) in front of the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 317, 133, 336]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 317, 920, 351]]<|/det|> The horizontal speed is the same on the Moon and the ball hits the floor \(4.0 \text{m}\) in front of the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 134, 376]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 357, 920, 390]]<|/det|> The horizontal speed is the same on the Moon and the ball hits the floor more than \(4.0 \text{m}\) in front of the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 418, 96, 435]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 418, 920, 450]]<|/det|> Diagram 1 shows a piece of flexible material that contains many pockets of air. massweight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 268, 307, 286]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 642, 134, 660]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 824, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 680, 920, 714]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 726, 517, 744]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 755, 134, 772]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 781, 514, 799]]<|/det|>

collision with another pollen grain due to their kinetic energies

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 510, 276]]<|/det|> 1 kg of each metal is put into 5 kg of each liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 289, 907, 307]]<|/det|> The starting temperature of each metal is \(60^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The starting temperature of each liquid is \(10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 534, 337]]<|/det|> Which example has the highest final temperature? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 489, 477]]<|/det|>
metalliquid
Aaluminiumethanol

Caluminiumwater
Dironwater
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 505, 106, 523]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 420, 523]]<|/det|> Metals are good thermal conductors. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 535, 443, 552]]<|/det|> Insulators are poor thermal conductors. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 698, 583]]<|/det|> Which description of the mechanism of thermal conductivity is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 593, 134, 611]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 593, 828, 611]]<|/det|> In insulators, conduction takes place by electron transfer and molecular vibrations. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 619, 134, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 619, 662, 636]]<|/det|> In insulators, conduction takes place by electron transfer only. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 134, 662]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 803, 662]]<|/det|> In metals, conduction takes place by electron transfer and molecular vibrations. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 134, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 670, 638, 688]]<|/det|> In metals, conduction takes place by electron transfer only.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> A teacher shows his class a polystyrene cup. The cup is made from thick plastic with lots of tiny air bubbles in it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 920, 150]]<|/det|> He asks the class why the cup is so good at keeping a hot drink warm. Three suggestions are made. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 163, 207, 180]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 163, 625, 180]]<|/det|> It contains air which is a poor thermal conductor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 188, 205, 205]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 188, 789, 205]]<|/det|> The air is trapped in tiny bubbles so very little convection is possible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 214, 205, 231]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 214, 551, 231]]<|/det|> The plastic is a poor thermal conductor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 243, 381, 261]]<|/det|> Which suggestions are correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 272, 133, 290]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 272, 203, 290]]<|/det|> 1 and 2 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 272, 250, 290]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 272, 425, 290]]<|/det|> 1 and 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 272, 470, 290]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 272, 541, 290]]<|/det|> 2 and 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[565, 272, 585, 290]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[598, 272, 641, 290]]<|/det|> 1, 2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 317, 107, 336]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 317, 920, 350]]<|/det|> A boy jumps into an indoor swimming pool. He notices that the water appears to get colder as he goes deeper underwater. This is due to convection. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 362, 348, 380]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 392, 133, 409]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 392, 804, 409]]<|/det|> Cold water is more dense than warm water so it sinks to the bottom of the pool. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 416, 133, 435]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 416, 804, 433]]<|/det|> Warm water is more dense than cold water so it rises to the surface of the pool. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 443, 133, 462]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 443, 920, 476]]<|/det|> The molecules in cold water have more kinetic energy than the molecules in warm water so they move to the bottom of the pool faster. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 484, 133, 502]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 484, 920, 516]]<|/det|> The molecules in warm water are closer together than the molecules in cold water so they rise to the surface of the pool. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 543, 106, 562]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 823, 561]]<|/det|> Four students A, B, C and D, investigate the diffraction of water waves through a gap. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 572, 546, 692]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 705, 828, 723]]<|/det|> Each student uses a different gap size and a different wavelength for the water waves. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 736, 678, 753]]<|/det|> Which student produces the waves which have the most diffraction? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 765, 489, 911]]<|/det|>
gap size
/cm		wavelength
/cm
A2.01.8
B3.02.1
C4.02.0
D5.00.9

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|> The wavelength of blue light changes from \(4.7 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}\) to \(3.5 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}\) as it passes from air to water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 443, 135]]<|/det|> What is the speed of this light in water? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 147, 134, 165]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 146, 268, 164]]<|/det|> \(7.4 \times 10^{7} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 174, 134, 192]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 173, 270, 191]]<|/det|> \(1.3 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 201, 134, 219]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 200, 270, 218]]<|/det|> \(2.2 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 228, 134, 246]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 227, 270, 245]]<|/det|> \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 273, 104, 291]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 272, 920, 306]]<|/det|> The diagram shows compressions and rarefactions in air as a sound wave moves from left to right. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 306, 892, 453]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 466, 512, 485]]<|/det|> A quieter sound of the same frequency is made. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 922, 530]]<|/det|> What will happen to the number of particles in a region of rarefaction and in a region of compression? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 541, 618, 686]]<|/det|>

<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 476, 920, 511]]<|/det|>
When Rutherford bombarded thin gold foil with \(\alpha\) -particles, he found that some \(\alpha\) -particles were deflected through large angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 522, 460, 540]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this deflection?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 551, 134, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 551, 500, 568]]<|/det|>
Most of the atom consists of empty space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 578, 131, 596]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 577, 920, 610]]<|/det|>
All of the positive charge and most of the mass of the gold atom are concentrated in a small volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 618, 131, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 618, 734, 636]]<|/det|>
Positive charge in the gold atom is spread evenly throughout the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 645, 133, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 645, 601, 663]]<|/det|>
All of the negative charge is concentrated at its centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the path followed by \(\alpha \cdot\) particles as they pass between two charged plates. They are deflected downwards.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 114, 761, 229]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 243, 682, 264]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 273, 134, 292]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 625, 292]]<|/det|>
They are deflected downwards more than the \(\alpha\) -particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 300, 134, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 300, 390, 317]]<|/det|>
They are deflected upwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 326, 134, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 326, 390, 344]]<|/det|>
They are not deflected at all.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 352, 134, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 352, 732, 371]]<|/det|>
They are deflected downwards by the same amount as the \(\alpha\) -particles.
